title: 105_hr2380
content: The "Internet Gambling Prohibition Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Definitions are provided in Section 2. Section 1081 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to update language regarding communication facilities. The amendment to Section 1081 of title 18, United States Code, updates language regarding communication facilities and defines the term 'bets or wagers' as the staking of something of value on the outcome of a contest of chance or future event predominantly subject to chance. The amendment to Section 1081 of title 18, United States Code, updates language regarding communication facilities and defines 'bets or wagers' as the staking of something of value on the outcome of a contest of chance. This includes purchasing a chance to win a prize subject to pure chance and information intended for betting or wagering. It excludes bona fide business transactions governed by securities laws. The curr_chunk defines 'bets or wagers' as the purchase or sale of securities, a contract of indemnity or guarantee, or a contract for insurance. Information assisting in placing bets or wagers is necessary for placing a bet by means of a bet or wagering business. The curr_chunk prohibits the use of communication facilities for placing bets or wagers in interstate or foreign commerce. The curr_chunk prohibits the transmission of wagering information and imposes penalties. The curr_chunk amends Section 1084 of title 18, United States Code, by prohibiting the use of communication facilities for transmitting bets or wagers in interstate or foreign commerce, with penalties of fines or imprisonment up to 4 years. The amended Section 1084 of title 18, United States Code prohibits the use of communication facilities for transmitting bets or wagers in interstate or foreign commerce. Those found guilty could face fines or imprisonment for up to 6 months. Exceptions include news reporting and legal bets and wagers. The amended Section 1084 of title 18, United States Code prohibits the use of communication facilities for transmitting bets or wagers in interstate or foreign commerce, with exceptions for legal betting activities. The amended Section 1084 of title 18, United States Code requires physical presence at licensed establishments to place bets or engage in contests. State laws are not preempted. Common carriers and interactive computer service providers have specific duties outlined in the amendment. The amended Section 1084 of title 18, United States Code allows State or local law enforcement agencies to obtain injunctive relief to prevent the use of facilities for transmitting gambling information in violation of laws. Stylistic amendment is made to Section 1084(e) by inserting a definition. The Congress believes that the Federal Government should have jurisdiction over the transmission and receipt of bets, wager information, and communications related to gambling. The Attorney General must submit a report to Congress within one year of this Act's enactment. The report should include an analysis of issues with enforcing section 1084 of title 18, United States Code, as amended by this Act, and recommendations for the Department of Justice's resources to enforce that section.
